questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of antidepressants?
questions.explanation:
348 
Sold by @itachibot Antidepressants increase levels of neurotransmitters at the synapse by preventing their reuptake. 
Due to a prolonged increase in the levels of neurotransmitters, there is a change in 
neurotransmitter receptor sensitivity which is thought to be the major mechanism responsible for 
the treatment of depression. Chronic treatment with a number of antidepressants desensitizes presynaptic autoreceptors and 
heteroreceptors, producing long-lasting changes in monoaminergic neurotransmission. 
Postreceptor effects of antidepressant treatment, including modulation of GPCR signaling and 
activation of protein kinases and ion channels, are involved in the mediation of the long-term 
effects of antidepressant drugs.

questions.question: Question 2: Moclobemide belongs to which class of drugs?
questions.explanation:
Moclobemide is a reversible and selective inhibitor of the MAO-A enzyme. Monoamine hypothesis states that in depression, there is a decrease in monoamines like serotonin 
(5HT) and norepinephrine. These monoamines are metabolized by the enzyme monoamine 
oxidase (MAO). MAO inhibitors, therefore, increase these monoamines by inhibiting the enzyme. The various classes of drugs used in depression and anxiety are listed below: Class of drugs 
Examples FluoxetineFluvoxamineParox 
etineSertralineCitalopram Selective serotonin reuptake i 
nhibitors (SSRI) Serotonin-norepinephrine re 
uptake inhibitors VenlafaxineDesvenlafaxineD 
uloxetineMilnacipran Tricyclic antidepressants 
AmitriptylineImipramineNor 
triptylineDesipramineAmoxa 
pine Atypical antipsychotics 
AripiprazoleOlanzapineQueti 
apineRisperidone IsocarboxazidSelegilinePhene 
lzineMoclobemide Monoamine oxidase inhibitor 
s (MAO) Atypical antidepressants 
BupropionTrazodoneMirtaza 
pineMianserin

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following is a selective MAO-B inhibitor?
questions.explanation:
Selegiline is a selective MAO-B inhibitor. Nonselective MAO inhibitors 
Selective MAO inhibitors MAO-A inhibitors - Moclobe 
mideMAO-B inhibitors - Sele 
giline, Rasagiline PhenelzineIsocarboxazidTran 
ylcypromine 349 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 4: In which of the following patients is transdermal selegiline approved for use?
questions.explanation:
Selegiline transdermal patch is approved for depression. The transdermal patch provides the high 
concentration required for antidepressant action. At higher doses, MAO-A is also inhibited and is 
highly effective in depression. Selegiline is a selective MAO-B inhibitor at low doses. It is used in Parkinson's disease at low 
doses, administered orally.

questions.question:
Question 5: A college student on MAO inhibitor therapy for depression consumed two bottles of beer 
during a party. The next day he started experiencing severe headache, nausea, and vomiting. 
He was taken to the casualty by his friends where his BP was recorded to be 180/110mmHg. 
Which of the following compounds would be responsible for this complication?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical presentation of a hypertensive crisis in a patient on MAO inhibitor therapy is 
suggestive of cheese reaction, which is seen after consumption of foods rich in tyramine (beer). Tyramine is an indirect sympathomimetic. It induces the release of catecholamines from the 
neurons. Tyramine can be produced in high concentrations in protein-rich foods by 
decarboxylation of tyrosine during fermentation. Normally tyramine is inactivated when taken orally because it is readily metabolized by MAO in 
the liver. In patients who are on MAO inhibitor therapy, the tyramine taken in the diet is not 
inactivated and results in its increased sympathomimetic effect resulting in elevated blood 
pressure, termed as hypertensive crisis or cheese reaction. Drug of choice for cheese reaction is IV 
phentolamine. When MAO inhibitors are taken along with SSRI or TCA, it results in serotonin syndrome due to 
the overstimulation of 5HT receptors. The clinical features are a triad of: • Cognitive effect - delirium, coma • Autonomic effects- hypertension, tachycardia • Somatic effects- myoclonus, hyperreflexia, tremors 350 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 6: A patient presents to the medicine OPD with hypertension. He is already on imipramine for 
depression. Which of the following antihypertensive drugs will not be effective in him?
questions.explanation:
Clonidine will not be effective in this patient. Imipramine, a tricyclic antidepressant would abolish the antihypertensive effect of clonidine, by 
inhibiting its transport into the adrenergic neurons. Side effects of tricyclic antidepressants: Receptor blocked 
Side effects Muscarinic receptor 
Anticholinergic - Dry mouth, 
dilated pupils, tachycardia, u 
rinary retention Alpha 1 adrenergic receptor 
Drowsiness, postural hypoten 
sion, sexual dysfunction H1 receptor 
Weight gain, drowsiness

questions.question: Question 7: Which tricyclic antidepressant has an additional dopaminergic receptor antagonist action?
questions.explanation:
The tricyclic antidepressant having an additional dopaminergic receptor antagonist action is 
amoxapine. Tricyclic antidepressants block the transporter of norepinephrine (NET) and serotonin (SERT) 
thereby preventing their uptake. Some of the TCA additionally block other receptors like alpha 1, 
H1, and M1. • TCA blocking NET selectively - desipramine, nortriptyline, amoxapine. • TCA blocking both NET and SERT equally - imipramine, amitriptyline. 351 
Sold by @itachibot Clomipramine, doxepin, and imipramine are tertiary amines and do not possess any 
dopaminergic antagonist effect.

questions.question:
Question 8: Which of the following antidepressants can be used for the treatment of a 6-year-old child 
diagnosed with nocturnal enuresis? 342 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation: Imipramine is a tricyclic antidepressant that can be used for the treatment of nocturnal enuresis. In children above 5 years, imipramine 25 mg at bedtime is effective for nocturnal enuresis. Intranasal desmopressin is also effective in the treatment of nocturnal enuresis. Option B: Amitriptyline is used in postherpetic neuralgia. It is also used in neuropathic pain. Option C: Desipramine is used in the treatment of cocaine dependence. Option D: Clomipramine is the best TCA for OCD.

questions.question:
Question 9: Which of the following side effects of tricyclic antidepressants are correctly matched to the 
receptor involved in their pathogenesis?
questions.explanation:
The blockade of H1, alpha1, and muscarinic receptors causes sedation, postural hypotension, and 
constipation respectively. Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) are drugs that act by inhibiting the reuptake of noradrenaline 
and serotonin from the synaptic clefts. The side effects of TCAs are due to blockade of other receptors: • Muscarinic (M) receptors: constipation, dry mouth (not sialorrhea), arrhythmia • Histamine (H1) receptors: sedation • 5HT receptors: weight gain due to increased appetite • Alpha1 receptors: postural hypotension

questions.question:
Question 10: A 30-year-old woman having depression took multiple tablets of amitriptyline in an attempt 
to commit suicide. Which of the following statements regarding the management is incorrect?

options.b: Sodium bicarbonate should be administered to treat acidosis
options.c: Atropine sulphate should be administered as an antidote
options.d: Diazepam should be injected to control seizures

questions.explanation:
Tricyclic antidepressants like amitriptyline are competitive antagonists of muscarinic receptors. 
Atropine being an antimuscarinic drug should not be administered. Tricyclic antidepressant overdose presents with anticholinergic effects. Hypotension occurs 
because of alpha1 receptor blockade. TCAs act on Na+ channels and cause slowed conduction and depressed cardiac contractility 
resulting in serious arrhythmias. Seizures and agitation may occur followed by depression. Management of TCA overdose: • Initial resuscitation by securing airway, breathing, and circulation. • Hypotension - IV fluids and norepinephrine infusion. 352 
Sold by @itachibot • Cardiac-depressant effects - bolus dose of sodium bicarbonate helps overcome Na+ blockade by 
increasing extracellular Na+. It also addresses metabolic acidosis which is often present. • Arrhythmias - lignocaine for ventricular arrhythmias. • Seizures - benzodiazepines like diazepam/lorazepam. Physostigmine can reverse anticholinergic effects but can aggravate cardiac depression and cause 
seizures. Therefore physostigmine is not recommended.

questions.question:
Question 11: A psychiatrist plans to prescribe an SSRI to a patient diagnosed with generalized anxiety 
disorder. Which of the following was not likely prescribed?
questions.explanation:
Duloxetine is not an SSRI but a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI). It blocks the 
uptake of both serotonin and norepinephrine. The selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) are: • Fluoxetine • Fluvoxamine • Citalopram • Escitalopram • Sertraline • Dapoxetine • Paroxetine

questions.question:
Question 12: 343 
Sold by @itachibot In a middle-aged man with a history of closed-angle glaucoma, which of the following SNRIs 
should be avoided?
questions.explanation:
Duloxetine should be avoided as it is contraindicated in patients with closed-angle 
glaucoma. SNRIs like duloxetine and milnacipran have anticholinergic side effects like 
mydriasis which can precipitate closed-angle glaucoma attacks. Duloxetine is the longest-acting SNRI with no withdrawal symptoms. In addition to the treatment 
of depression and anxiety, it is also used in fibromyalgia, peripheral neuropathy, and stress 
incontinence. Option A: Venlafaxine is the shortest acting SNRI with the maximum risk of withdrawal 
symptoms. It is approved for use in PTSD, panic disorder, and depression associated with 
hypotension. It is contraindicated in pregnancy. Option C: Desvenlafaxine is a longer-acting SNRI and hence has lesser risk of withdrawal 
symptoms. Option D: Fluoxetine is an SSRI, not an SNRI. It is avoided as it can cause mydriasis and narrow 
the angle. 353 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 13: A 27-year-old man on antidepressant therapy with TCAs for the past five years is being 
switched to SSRIs. Which of the following would not be an advantage of this change?
questions.explanation:
SSRIs have a higher incidence of sexual dysfunction when compared to TCAs. SSRI-induced sexual dysfunction can result in loss of libido, delayed ejaculation, and interference 
with orgasm. Option A: The potential of SSRIs to lower the seizure threshold is less than that of TCAs. Options B and D: SSRIs have a selective action on serotonin reuptake with no effect on cholinergic 
or histaminergic receptors.

questions.question:
Question 14: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors are not the drug of choice in which of the following 
patients?

options.a: A college student with an acute panic attack
options.b: An adolescent girl with social phobia
options.c: A young lady with post traumatic stress disorder
options.d: A middle-aged-man with generalized anxiety disorder

questions.explanation:
In acute panic attacks, benzodiazepines or propranolol are the preferred anxiolytics. SSRIs are not 
the drug of choice as they have a long latent period before beneficial effects are seen. SSRIs are considered as the drug of choice for: • Social anxiety disorder • Post-traumatic stress disorder • Generalized anxiety disorder • Obsessive-compulsive disorder

questions.question:
Question 15: A patient diagnosed with depression has improved symptomatically after initiating SSRIs. On 
discontinuing the drug, he became irritable and complained of insomnia, nausea, and flu-like 
symptoms. Which of the following drugs has the least risk of causing these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical presentation is suggestive of drug discontinuation or withdrawal symptoms 
which are seen after sudden discontinuation of SSRIs. Fluoxetine has the least risk of causing 
drug-discontinuation symptoms. Drug discontinuation symptoms of SSRIs are: • Nausea • Paresthesia • Flu-like symptoms • Insomnia • Irritability • Fatigue. Withdrawal is least with fluoxetine as its metabolite norfluoxetine has the longest half-life. Thus 
the plasma level of norfluoxetine is maintained for a long time even after stopping the drug, 
minimizing withdrawal symptoms. Withdrawal is seen maximum with paroxetine.

questions.question:
Question 16: A young man with obsessive-compulsive disorder is taking SSRIs. Which of the following 
adverse effects would you not expect in him?
questions.explanation:
354 
Sold by @itachibot Weight loss is not an adverse effect of SSRIs. Side effects of SSRIs: • Nausea and diarrhea (early) • Loss of libido • Erectile dysfunction • Headache • Sleep disturbances - insomnia or hypersomnia.

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following drugs is a serotonin receptor antagonist?
questions.explanation:
Trazodone is a serotonin receptor antagonist. Trazodone blocks postsynaptic 5HT2A receptors and is considered an atypical antidepressant. It 
has weak serotonin reuptake inhibitory effect. Nefazodone is another serotonin receptor antagonist. Option A: Milnacipran is a serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor. Options C and D: Citalopram and fluoxetine are selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors.

questions.question: Question 18: Which of the following drugs inhibit dopamine and noradrenaline reuptake?
questions.explanation:
Bupropion is an atypical antidepressant that inhibits the reuptake of noradrenaline and 
dopamine. Indications of bupropion are: • Prevention of a seasonal depressive disorder • Smoking cessation • ADHD • Peripheral neuropathy Option A : Clozapine is an atypical antipsychotic that selectively blocks dopamine (D4) receptors 
in the brain. Option C : Zolpidem - It is a nonbenzodiazepine hypnotic. It acts as a selective agonist in 
benzodiazepine receptor. Option D : Mirtazapine - block histamine (H1) receptors.

questions.question:
Question 19: A young woman diagnosed with major depressive disorder is refractory to first-line 
antidepressant therapy. The psychiatrist now decides to prescribe a recently approved NMDA 
antagonist. Which of the following was most likely prescribed?
questions.explanation:
355 
Sold by @itachibot Esketamine is an NMDA antagonist recently approved for the treatment of 
treatment-resistant depression. Esketamine is a non-selective, non-competitive antagonist of the NMDA receptor, an ionotropic 
glutamate receptor. Though the exact mechanism by which it acts as an antidepressant is 
unknown, a single dose of intranasal Esketamine has shown to have short-term antidepressant 
efficacy suggesting a possible use in suicidality. Option A: Brexanolone has GABAA modulatory action. It is given via intravenous route for 
post-partum depression. Option C: Lurasidone is a second-generation antipsychotic that is an antagonist at dopamine (D2) 
and serotonin (5-HT2A) receptors. It is approved for use in depressive episodes in bipolar 
disorder. Option D: Lemborexant is an orexin receptor antagonist indicated for the treatment of adult 
patients with insomnia.

questions.question:
Question 20: A 30-year-old married man complains of low energy and lack of motivation. He mentions that 
he feels useless and has no hope for the future. He is willing to take medication but is 
apprehensive about its side effects on his sexual life. Which of the following drugs would you 
prescribe to him?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical presentation is suggestive of depression. Mirtazapine can be prescribed to this 
patient as sexual dysfunction is not a side effect associated with its use. Mirtazapine and mianserin block histamine (H1) receptors, and also have high antagonistic 
activity against 5HT2A, 5HT2C, and 5HT3 receptors. Due to its sedative effect, mirtazapine is also used in depression with insomnia. Option A: Fluoxetine is an SSRI that can cause side effects like GI disturbances, risk of suicidal 
behavior, sexual dysfunction, and weight gain. Vilazodone is an SSRI that is not associated with 
sexual dysfunction or weight gain. Option B: SNRIs like venlafaxine have side effects that include nausea, dizziness, sexual 
dysfunction, and risk of suicidal thoughts or behavior. Option D: TCAs like imipramine have side effects like orthostatic hypotension, weight gain, GI 
disturbances, sexual dysfunction, seizures, and irregular heartbeats. The various classes of drugs used in depression and anxiety are listed below Class of drugs 
Examples FluoxetineFluvoxamineParox 
etineSertralineCitalopram Selective serotonin reuptake i 
nhibitors (SSRI) Serotonin-norepinephrine re 
uptake inhibitors VenlafaxineDesvenlafaxineD 
uloxetineMilnacipran Tricyclic antidepressants 
AmitriptylineImipramineNor 
triptylineDesipramineAmoxa 
pine Atypical antipsychotics 
AripiprazoleOlanzapineQueti 
apineRisperidone 356

Examples IsocarboxazidSelegilinePhene 
lzine Monoamine oxidase inhibitor 
s (MAO) Atypical antidepressants 
BupropionTrazodoneMirtaza 
pineMianserin

questions.question: Question 21: Which group does the antianxiety drug buspirone belong to?
questions.explanation:
The antianxiety drug buspirone is a partial agonist of 5-HT1A receptors. The most important 
locations of the 5-HT1A receptor are raphe nuclei of brainstem and hippocampus. It mimics the antianxiety properties of benzodiazepines but does not interact with GABAA 
receptors or display the sedative and anticonvulsant properties of benzodiazepines. Buspirone is 
primarily used in the treatment of generalized anxiety disorder. 5-HT1A partial agonists are: • Buspirone • Gepirone • Ipsapirone

questions.question:
Question 22: A psychiatry resident should not prescribe a tricyclic antidepressant to a patient having which 
of the following co-morbidities?
questions.explanation:
Tricyclic antidepressants produce anticholinergic effects of pupillary dilatation and are thus, 
contraindicated in narrow-angle glaucoma. Side effects of tricyclic antidepressants: Receptor blocked 
Side effect Muscarinic receptor 
Anticholinergic- dry mouth, 
dilated pupils, tachycardia, u 
rinary retention Alpha 1 adrenergic receptor 
Drowsiness, postural hypoten 
sion, sexual dysfunction H1 receptor 
Weight gain, drowsiness

questions.question:
Question 23: A 35-year-old man was admitted to the emergency ward with priapism lasting for about 7 
hours. A detailed history revealed the initiation of a drug for a mood disorder by a 346 
Sold by @itachibot psychiatrist 3 weeks ago. Which of the following drugs is responsible for his condition?
questions.explanation:
Trazadone causes priapism. Intracavernous injection of phenylephrine can be used to treat 
priapism. 357 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 24: A man feels frustrated because of his wife's decreased sexual desire. She was recently 
diagnosed with depression and started on a drug for the same. Which of the following drugs 
was most likely prescribed?
questions.explanation:
Fluoxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) that is associated with the side effect 
of sexual dysfunction. Fluoxetine is used in the treatment of major depression, obsessive-compulsive disorder, 
post-traumatic stress disorder, bulimia and anorexia nervosa, generalized anxiety disorders, and 
premenstrual dysphoric disorder. Other adverse effects include dry mouth, urinary retention, insomnia, GI disturbances, risk of 
suicidal behavior, and weight gain.

questions.question: Question 25: Which of the following is not an adverse effect of escitalopram?
questions.explanation:
Sialorrhoea is not an adverse effect of escitalopram. Escitalopram is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) mainly used to treat major 
depressive disorder or generalized anxiety disorder. Nausea is the commonest side effect of SSRIs as they target the 5HT3 receptor. Vivid dreams may occur because the drug suppresses REM sleep (the stage of dream), hence when 
patients eventually fall into REM sleep it may be more intense. Anorgasmia is the persistent inability to achieve orgasm despite responding to sexual stimulation. 
A proposed mechanism of escitalopram causing sexual dysfunction involves stimulation of the 
5HT2C receptors.

questions.question:
Question 26: In children and adolescents treated with an SSRI, there appears to be an increased risk of 
particular ideations. Clinicians are therefore advised to remain vigilant of which of the 
following?
questions.explanation:
Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) should be used carefully in the young for the 
management of depression due to increased suicidal ideation. In children and adolescents, there 
appears to be a slightly increased risk of suicidal ideations and attempts, but not of completed 
suicide. Somatic symptoms of depression improve faster than psychological symptoms when a patient is 
started on SSRIs and hence patients have the energy to act on their thoughts of deliberate 
self-harm and suicide (paradoxical suicide). 358 
Sold by @itachibot Opioids - Functions and Classification
